description: 1660s; borrowed from French sénile, from Middle French senile, from Old French senile, from Latin senīlis (“of or pertaining to old age”), from senex (“old man”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sénos (“old”).

adjectives.description: senile (comparative more senile, superlative most senile)

entries.meaning: Of, or relating to old age.
(often offensive) Exhibiting the deterioration in mind and body often accompanying old age; doddering.
(dated, medicine) A person who is senile.
